embeds.title: Radiant Flame
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Whenever you Ignite a Ghostflame, gain 3 (4) **Block** :p_block:.

messages.content: @Blue Guy
go on about this card
block power = OP
Ah yes
I have to finish this collector run first.
you know, like...feel no pain? mental fortress?
yeah
the best defensive scaling hexa has
But I'm extremely fond of this card.
Ghost shield's 2nd in command in the "busted block cards" dept.
~~"extremely fond" sounds like a euphenism~~
The issue is that it's the ONLY real defensive scaling hexaghost has, unless you consider gifts from beyond defensive scaling, or footwork afterlife edition defensive scaling.
oh i mentioned it by name, god forgive me

I would consider burning question defensive scaling
but it's not great
gifts from beyond is just "get your *you know what* back"
It's really cool but the overall lack of defensive scaling powers makes this card overcentralizing, and makes runs on ascension 20 always fall into the same 2 archetypes defensively.
is the second one *you know what*?

The Spirit Brand is a great starter, and this is basically giving you an additional stack of it, and allowing for more block with multiple ignitions in a turn, so with advance, forked flame, and haunting echo.
So this power is basically required, because floatwork isn't going to do shit.
The way to solve this is to make the other uncommon powers not complete dogshit.
barring the seals, obviously.
<gain 3 intensity>

embeds.title: Empowered Flame
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Gain 2 (3) **Intensity** :p_intensity:.

messages.content: <floatwork>

embeds.title: Floatwork
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

**Ethereal**. **Afterlife.**
Gain 3 (4) Plated Armor.

messages.content: <devil's dance>

embeds.title: Devil's Dance
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 2 (1) :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

The first time you Retract each turn, gain :energy_hexa: and draw 1 card.
**Retract.**

messages.content: ah yes
floatwork certainly exists
well floatwork tries
but it fails
miserably
empowered flame just isn't good enough, especially considering that infernal form exists.
and devil's dance uhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh
Intensity is great, but 3 isn't really enough unless you're pushing your ghostflames hard, and if you're pushing your ghostflames hard, radiant flame is going to do significantly more work.
The thing is, comparing intensity to focus, defect can channel tons of orbs and they work passively, so even 1 focus is huge in longer fights.
Intensity has a better short term effect in hallways since you just have to play cards of the required type over channeling an orb.
so if you get a LOT of intensity, it starts to pick up. Or if you start with some intensity <tobsco> <the broken seal>, it starts to pick up too.

embeds.title: Jar of TOBSCo
embeds.description:
Common Relic / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Start each combat with 1 **Intensity** :p_intensity:.
*A little extra heat makes everything better.*

embeds.title: The Broken Seal
embeds.description:
Special Relic / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Upon pickup, raise your Max HP by 10, then heal all of your HP. Start each combat with 2 **Strength** :p_strength:, 2 **Dexterity** :p_dexterity:, and 2 **Intensity** :p_intensity:. You can not receive The Broken Seal again.
*Unlimited, unrestrained, unquenchable power.*

messages.content: But almost all the time, intensity is offensive rather than defensive, with the bolstering flame being an exception.
And while there are ways to abuse the bolster like <olexa's shield> or <forked flame> or even <catch up>, this isn't absolutely consistent over radiant flames pure consistency.

embeds.title: Olexa's Shield
embeds.description:
Shop Relic / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Swap the positions of the Bolstering Ghostflame and the first Searing Ghostflame.
*Protection on-demand.*

embeds.title: Forked Flame
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Deal 5 (8) damage.
**Ignite** the previous, then the next Ghostflames.

embeds.title: Catch Up
embeds.description:
Uncommon Skill / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

**Ignite** the previous Ghostflame 2 times.
​~~- **Exhaust**. -~~

messages.content: So I do think that empowered flame could use +1 intensity to give it some form of value over infernal form, that being cost and slightly more short term power, while still keeping infernal form objectively better as a rare compared to an uncommon.
how would you change floatwork?

This would make it better as an offensive power, but since it's kind of obligatory to have a power like this, there's no way to make it work defensively, since the amount of intensity you need to make it work defensively is extremely large.

Floatwork is just kind of fucked. It builds upon this idea that hexaghost gets block passively, your starter relic, the 2 afterlife block cards, the bolster flame, radiant flame (some of these are better than others but they all basically give you some amount of passive block for following the requirements of your ghostflames, so rewarding the character's main gimmick or facilitating the ease of following it.
@zero-113 Slimeboss Enjoyer it'll take a minute
anyways
floatwork builds on this idea by saying "hey you can ignite more easily because you get a lil bit of free block every turn so it's easier to do the stuff you want to do"
but if you let it afterlife, it takes a turn to start working
this is bad, because while burning question can get away with it because dexterity is good, plated armor is a flat amount of block rather than a scaled amount.
why doesn't float work give you dex
would make the name of the card make sense

what I would do is make floatwork have some immediate effect, even if you let it afterlife, and have some kind of interaction with making the bolster flame better, like "the amount of block and strength you get from the bolstering ghostflame is doubled", or make it based around advancing, like "advancing or retracting grants 2 (3) temporary dexterity, including the end of turn advance"
name one bad block power in the game
devil's dance is just insanely bad
it flat out requires an upgrade.
can you hear me btw
and the amount of support you get for it is extremely limited
and you it needs multiple copies to start working
I genuinely have no idea how you'd rework it. Honestly, I'd just remove it entirely and replace it with a different power.
Retracting is most of the time, a punishment.

There are some situations where it can do stuff, namely with the bolstering ghostflame, but it's too inconsistent considering it takes until turn 3 or 4 depending to get to the second searing ghostflame in a "normal" deck.
And the only renewable sources of retract are float+ and backtrack smack.

and you'll need a power every single time barring forked flame or catch up, which aren't retract support at all, but rather all around multi synergy good stuff and a bolster support card respectively.
retract is just genuinely fucked
I do think that floatwork is salvageable, but devil's dance is not.
So devil's dance is a card that rewards you for doing something you rarely want to do
I can't think of any other hexa powers that do something similar
poltergeist
which is another can of worms but I'm talking about the uncommon powers
there's also the first 4 of the 6 seals, which are meant to have no in combat effect, so they get a pass
unless the payoff of your power is huge, if it does nothing turn of, that's REALLY bad
powers are of course better on hexaghost because playing them is easier (again, passive block is something that comes up a lot)
but powers should serve a purpose instead of just igniting the bolster most of the time
that's kindle's job
oh and there's also <speedrunning> (complete meme card) and <extra crispy> (olexa's shield / incineration card)

embeds.title: Speedrunning
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 0 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

 (**Innate**.)
Whenever you Advance, gain 2 temporary :p_temp: **Strength** :p_strength:.

embeds.title: Extra Crispy
embeds.description:
Uncommon Power / 1 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

 (**Innate**.)
Cards and Ghostflames apply 2 more **Soulburn** :p_soulburn:.

messages.content: I hold nothing against incineration, support for olexa's shield is nice and incineration is a great card too, but speedrunning is also insanely fucked.
I guess I might give extra crispy +1 soulburn on the upgrade on top of the innate maybe.

Speedrunning however, is very hard to actually make work outside of <impeccable pecs> abuse because the amount of payoff it has, incineration being a strength card and <time warp> being a strength and advance payoff as well as an ignite and intensity enabler, BOTH being rares.

embeds.title: Impeccable Pecs
embeds.description:
Uncommon Relic / All / Downfall

Whenever you gain **Strength** :p_strength:, gain an equal amount of Temporary :p_temp:_HP.
Start each combat with 1 **Strength** :p_strength:.
*Glorious.*

embeds.title: Time Warp
embeds.description:
Rare Attack / 0 :energy_hexa: / The Hexaghost / Downfall

Deal 4 (6) damage.
Whenever you Advance or Retract, return this from the discard pile.

messages.content: speedrunning could give a flat amount of block on top of the temporary strength and it would be good, like gain 4 block whenever you advance, so you would gain 4 block at the end of your turn making it have some kind of payoff every turn (most of the time)
and this would not be great, but it would build into the passive block idea and being rewarded for following the ghostflame instructions
it would also be a better version of floatwork lol

I guess what I'm getting at is that all of these powers suck which makes radiant flame, the only good one, very overcentralizing. And making these powers not suck would be healthier for the character allowing for more varied runs.
@zero-113 Slimeboss Enjoyer I finished the rant and I'll start the run again.

I don't have much to say about this card. This is a good metallize clone. On most turns this just gives 3 block per turn, which is fine but on occasion it can be a lot stronger when used with cards like forked flame that let the player ignite multiple ghost flames at once. This tends to not be the best act 1 pick, but with the aid of ghost shield you can just do it anyways and not get punished too hard for that choice.
it's closer to feel no pain than metalicize

As is true of most scaling block engine cards, this is very good. Critically you can trigger this the same turn you play it, which really helps offset the cost and give it a bit more front-loading as well. You really want to have ways to abuse this like forked flame, catch up, haunting echo, unlimited power, instant inferno+, again!, and advance cards to help you get multiple triggers each turn. I think that most hexaghost decks will still take this regardless though, as it's pretty easy to get 3 (4) -6 (8) block from it every turn without putting in very much work. Upgrade is very solid, though I wouldn't prioritize it until I had a few of those synergy cards that could help trigger this multiple times in a turn. It's probably a bit too generically good and easy to incorporate, I'm having difficulty imagining what hexaghost deck wouldn't take this. It doesn't help that hexaghost has very limited options for other forms of scaling block either, with burning questions dexterity being one of the only alternatives, and ghost shield recursion being another. 

Even in act 1 this is pretty strong, float and kindle help you trigger the ghostflames, it helps trigger bolstering ghostflame, and it performs well into tri-sentries and lagavulin, while being a little too slow and low impact for gremlin nob. The steady block will be very useful in the act 1 boss fight and beyond, taking off a lot of pressure from act 2 hallways and elites if you have the right synergies. Runic pyramid can help you hold onto cards that ignite multiple ghostflames to stockpile block on the right turns, and it's great with mummified hand, bolster rod, bird-faced urn, and bottled tornado.

Like water, Nirvana and Metallicize from the base game are all debatably weak. Part of that is just how good watchers other block options are, and because of how nasty awakened one is at A19 when you play low impact powers against them.
<nirvana>
